The number of people facing insufficient food consumption spiked sharply after the events of August 2021. Since then, some nine in ten households have faced insufficient food consumption each month.

More than one in five households in the analysed population were moderately food insecure, a worsening trend continuing since the previous month. Food security worsened nationwide in all the divisions due to increased expenditure and negative coping.
In Kiribati, the proportion of people who are food insecure has slightly changed, from 7 percent in Q3 2022 to 8 percent in Q2 2023. In Samoa, the trend is unchanged.
Food insecurity has slightly improved from 12 percent in March to 10 percent in June. Food insecurity was found to be highest in Talas, (16 percent) and Osh (15 percent) provinces.
Nearly one in seven households (13.3 percent) were food-insecure in April/May 2023. This has remained relatively stable in recent months but could worsen with inflation remaining at record highs.
A fifth of the population (3.9 million people) were food insecure in March 2022. This represents an improvement compared with May 2022, when 6.2 million were estimated to be moderately food insecure.
About one in four households are food insecure, with the states of Chin, Kayah, Kayin, Rakhine, and Sagaing having the worst food security outcomes across all indicators.
The proportion of people facing insufficient food consumption in October (18 percent) had worsened by about 5 percentage points compared with June 2022.

In Balochistan, Sindh, and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, 43 percent of the analysed population was projected to be food insecure from Jul-Dec 2022. The deterioration of the food security situation is due to the devastating impacts of the flooding.
Food security situation has slightly worsened, from 10 percent in Nov/Dec 2022 to 15 percent in Jan-March 2023.

Nearly one-fifth (18 percent) of households in Tajikistan were food-insecure in September 2023. Compared to May, the proportion of food-insecure households has slightly improved, by 3 percentage points.

300,000 people, or 22 percent of the population, have plunged into food insecurity due to high food prices, reduced purchasing power, persistent impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, and the recent flooding.
